intro: Rosa arvensis f. repens, commonly known as creeping wild rose, is a low-growing shrub that thrives in disturbed soils and open habitats. It is characterized by its prostrate or匍匐 (creeping) growth habit, with stems that root at the nodes. The plant produces simple, pinnately compound leaves and has fragrant, pink to white flowers that bloom in summer. Its fruit is a red, hairy rosehip that contains seeds. This species is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas, demonstrating its adaptability to various environments.
